verb.description: Make it easier for (someone) to do something by offering one's services or resources.
examples: she helped him find a buyer
the teenager helped out in the corner store
Roger's companion helped him with the rent
she helped herself to a cookie

synonyms: be unable to prevent oneself from
be unable to break the habit of

noun.description: The action of helping someone to do something; assistance.
examples: I asked for help from my neighbors

exclamation.description: Used as an appeal for urgent assistance.

phrases: And so help me God, if I ever see another montage again, something terrible is going to happen.
If he doesn't, he'll get the left-overs from last night, so help me!
But so help me, I just don't have the strength of will to do it.
So help me God, if you stop any member of my staff one more time for another one of your needless questions, you will be dealing with me.
When I put my hand on the Bible, I will swear to not only uphold the laws of our land, I will swear to uphold the honor and dignity of the office to which I have been elected, so help me God.
origin: Old English helpan (verb), help (noun), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch helpen and German helfen.
